# Alignment

## Alignment axiom

Two words shall be called aligned or alignable when their progressive Levenshtein distance is low, that is, when they have high phonetic similarity compatible with universal [sound-change](sound-change.html) correspondences.  

As such alignment is per se orthogonal to relatedness. However aligned words have a high (but not perfect) [chance](chance.html) of being [related](related.html) in the classical or extended senses, or through various forms of connectedness.  

Alignment is a soft form of [Phono-semantic-matching](Phono-semantic-matching.html) of loan words. The imported word keeps some of the sounds but the structure is severely altered to match _something_ within the target language.  

Alignment within the same language is called [reanalysis](reanalysis.html).  

Alignment within the same language family is excessively frequent.
